contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox VG | title = X-Out | image = [[File:X-OutBoxShotAmiga.jpg|200px|X-Out]] | caption = Cover art of ''X-Out'' | developer = [[Arc Development]] <br> [[Rainbow Arts]] | publisher = | released = 1989 <br> 1990 | genre = [[Shoot 'em up]] | modes = [[Single player]] | platforms = [[Amiga]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Atari ST]], [[Commodore 64|C64]], [[Commodore 128|C128]], [[Sinclair ZX Spectrum]], }} '''''X-Out''''' is a [[video game]] released by [[Rainbow Arts]] in 1989 for the [[Commodore 64]] and in 1990 for the [[Amiga]], [[Atari ST]], [[ZX Spectrum]] and [[Amstrad CPC]]. ==Gameplay== ''X-Out'' is a [[Shoot 'em up#Horizontal scrolling shooter|horizontally scrolling]] [[Shoot 'em up|shoot-em-up]] with eight levels and an underwater setting. Between levels, the player visits a shop and use their game score to purchase new submarines and equipment. The submarines come in four different variants, and additional purchases act as additional "lives". Each can be equipped with a one-way, two-way or three-way fire weapon of increasing power (and thus cost). Secondary weapons include sonic waves, powershots and target-seeking missiles. The player can also purchase auxiliary satellites and specify their movement pattern, which can be circular orbits, vertical and horizontal movements, or an intercepting action. ==Critical reception== The ZX Spectrum version achieved good critical success. [[Your Sinclair]] awarded 84%, highlighting the comprehensive shop sequence and large, well-animated enemies. Criticisms included the monochrome graphics which were said to be a little confusing, and the lack of a sense of danger.<ref name="YS">{{cite journal|journal=Your Sinclair|author=Bielby, Matt|issue=51|page=56|month=March|year=1990|title=X-Out review}}</ref> During the time of release, there was some debate as to whether the game was actually pronounced ''"cross out"'' or ''"X out"'' (''"ex out"'').<ref name="YS"/> However the cassette version of the Commodore 64 release displays "Loading Crossout" at the beginning of the loading process. Also, in the Amiga version (as well in the C64 version), the synthesized voice in the intro says "Get ready for Crossout". The sequel ''[[Z-Out]]'' abandons this pronunciation pattern. == External links == * [http://hol.abime.net/1611 Entry for ''X-Out'' at HOL] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1989 video games]] [[Category:Amiga games]] [[Category:Amstrad CPC games]] [[Category:Atari ST games]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum games]] [[Category:Scrolling shooters]] {{scroll-shooter-videogame-stub}}
